subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] what's the differences between Shavian and Read
msgSnippet: ... I agree with this.  One of the faults I found in Shavian was that too many of the letters are too similar.  I suspect that affects learning the alphabet
messageBody:
oliver langan wrote:

> > Shavian letters, on the other hand, are not connected. Advocates of
> > Shavian insist that this does not slow down writing, but I cannot
> > accept
> > this. If every new letter requires a penlift, it has to slow writing
> > down.
>
> I prefer the Read Alphabet even when the letters are not connected: the
> 'junior' version. Written this way, the alphabet is much more similar
> to Shavian, but the characters are more distinct from each other than
> in Shavian--there are far fewer cases where one character is simply a
> 180 degree shift of another--which I believe makes it easier to read.

I agree with this. One of the faults I found in Shavian was that too
many of the letters are too similar. I suspect that affects learning
the alphabet and building reading speed.

Paige G.

> I prefer the Read Alphabet even when the letters are not connected: the

> in Shavian--there are far fewer cases where one character is simply a

I agree with this.  One of the faults I found in Shavian was that too 
many of the letters are too similar.  I suspect that affects learning 
the alphabet and building reading speed.

Paige G.
